{"comments": {"id": 26680, "count": 35, "talk_id": 2063}, "threadId": 26680, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "2063", "description": "Ziyah Gafic\u0301 photographs everyday objects\u2014watches, shoes, glasses. But these images are deceptively simple; the items in them have been exhumed from the mass graves of the Bosnian War. Gafic\u0301, a TED Fellow and Sarajevo native, is photographing every item from these graves in order to create a living archive of the identities of those lost.\u00a0", "event": "TED2014", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Ziyah Gafic\u0301: Everyday objects, tragic histories", "slug": "ziyah_gafic_everyday_objects_tragic_histories", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "1818", "slug": "ziyah_gafic", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Ziyah", "lastname": "Gafic\u0301", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Photographer + storyteller", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/ff29d6c65cef2c5587e8fb404c9009fa3a18ebab_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "To help him come to terms with the tragedy of his own homeland, Bosnian photographer Ziyah Gafic\u0301 turns his camera on the aftermath of conflict, showing his images in galleries, in books and on Instagram.\r\n", "whylisten": "

Ziyah Gafic\u0301 uses his camera to capture the aftermath of war. He has traveled to Pakistan, Iraq and Chechnya to capture beautiful portraits of people carrying on with their lives in the face of destruction; he has photographed the everyday lives of children in Rwanda, a generation born from the widespread use of rape as a weapon during the Rwandan genocide. A moving question runs through his work: After war, how do people manage to keep the fabric of society together?

Gafic\u0301's interest in this subject comes from his own biography. Born in Sarajevo, he was a teenager during the Bosnian War of the 1990s. Through photography, he parses what happened in his homeland. For his book Quest for Identity, Gafic\u0301 photographed the watches, keys, shoes, combs and glasses exhumed from mass graves 20 years after the Bosnian War. These objects are cleaned, catalogued and used to help identify the bodies found with them, but afterwards, they become what Gafic\u0301 calls “orphans of the narrative,” either destroyed or stored away out of sight and out of mind. His quest is to keep them in view as a last testament to the fact that these people existed, preserving them as an easily accessible visual archive that tells the story of what happened—integrating an objective forensic perspective with human compassion.

"is_published": true, "firstname": "Ziyah", "lastname": "Gafic\u0301", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Photographer + storyteller", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/ff29d6c65cef2c5587e8fb404c9009fa3a18ebab_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "To help him come to terms with the tragedy of his own homeland, Bosnian photographer Ziyah Gafic\u0301 turns his camera on the aftermath of conflict, showing his images in galleries, in books and on Instagram.\r\n", "whylisten": "

Ziyah Gafic\u0301 uses his camera to capture the aftermath of war. He has traveled to Pakistan, Iraq and Chechnya to capture beautiful portraits of people carrying on with their lives in the face of destruction; he has photographed the everyday lives of children in Rwanda, a generation born from the widespread use of rape as a weapon during the Rwandan genocide. A moving question runs through his work: After war, how do people manage to keep the fabric of society together?

Gafic\u0301's interest in this subject comes from his own biography. Born in Sarajevo, he was a teenager during the Bosnian War of the 1990s. Through photography, he parses what happened in his homeland. For his book Quest for Identity, Gafic\u0301 photographed the watches, keys, shoes, combs and glasses exhumed from mass graves 20 years after the Bosnian War. These objects are cleaned, catalogued and used to help identify the bodies found with them, but afterwards, they become what Gafic\u0301 calls “orphans of the narrative,” either destroyed or stored away out of sight and out of mind. His quest is to keep them in view as a last testament to the fact that these people existed, preserving them as an easily accessible visual archive that tells the story of what happened—integrating an objective forensic perspective with human compassion.

"}], "speaker_name": "Ziyah Gafic\u0301", "tags": ["TED Fellows", "photography", "war"], "title": "Everyday objects, tragic histories", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1032081}]}
author: Ziyah_Gafić;
title: Everyday objects, tragic histories

aws-transcripts.transcript: thes are simple objects, clocks, keys, comes glasses. They're the things that victims of genocide in Bosnia carried with them on their final journey. We are all familiar with these mundane, everyday objects. The fact that some of the victims carried personal items such as a toothpaste and a toothbrush is a clear sign. They had no idea what was about to happen to them. Usually they were told that they were going to be exchanged for prisoners of war. These items have been recovered from numerous mass graves across my homeland. And as we speak, forensics are exhuming bodies from newly discovered mass grave 20 years after the war. And it is quite possibly the largest ever discovered during the four years of conflict. The devastated Boston nation. In the early nineties, approximately 30,000 citizens, mainly civilians when missing, presumed killed in another 100,000 were killed during combat operations. Most of them were killed during the early days of the war or towards the end of the hostilities, when you and save zones like Sabaneta fell into the hands of the Serb army. International Criminal Tribunal delivered a number of sentences for crimes against humanity and genocide genocide is a systematic and deliberate destruction off racial, political, religious or ethnic group. As much as genocide is about killing, it is also about destroying their property, their culture, heritage and ultimately, the very notion that ever existed. Genocide is not only about the killing, it is about the denied identity. There is always traces, no such thing as a perfect crime. There are always remnants of the perished one it's that are more durable than their fragile bodies and our selective and fading memory of them. These items are recovered from numerous mass graves, and the main goal of this collection of the items is a unique process off identifying those who disappeared in the killings, the first act of genocide on European soil since the Holocaust. No, the single body should remain undiscovered or unidentified. Once recovered. These items that victims carried with them on their way to execution are carefully cleaned, analyzed, cataloged and stored. Thousands of artifacts are packed in white plastic bags, just like the ones you Cmc aside. These objects are used as a forensic tool in visual identification of the victims, but they're also used as a very valuable forensic evidence in the ongoing war crimes trials. Survivors are occasionally called to try to identify these items physically, but physical browsing is extremely difficult and ineffective and painful process. Once the forensics and doctors and lawyers are done with these objects, they become orphans of the narrative. Many of them get destroyed, believe it or not, or they get simply shelved out of sight and out of mind. I decided few years ago to photograph every single exhumed item in order to create a visual archive that survivors could easily brows. As a storyteller, I like to give back to the community. I like to move beyond raising awareness, and in this case someone may recognize these items or ATT least their photographs. We remain as permanent, unbiased and accurate. Reminder off what happened. Photography is about empathy and familiarity of these items. Guarantee empathy. In this case, I am merely a tool, a forensic, if you like, and the results is a photography that is close as possible. Off being a document. Once all the missing persons are identified only decaying bodies in their graves and these everyday items will remain in all their simplicity, these items are the last testament to the identity of the victims, the last permanent reminder that these people ever existed. Thank you very much
